description:
This is the last blocker towards removing menus, and the grabs.

GtkComboBox needs to be ported to use a popover.

title: Windows NT 6.2 (Windows 8) not always DWM Enabled.
description:
If user install an extension (for example LeoShell), the DWM is **not always** enabled. 

Bad line:

  `win32_screen->always_composited = g_win32_check_windows_version (6, 2, 0, G_WIN32_OS_ANY);`

Correct line:

  `win32_screen->always_composited = 0;`


The features due to Microsoft spec (MSDN) shall always be checked by feature (in this case `DwmIsCompositionEnabled`). Do not check features by `GetVersion` or `GetVersionEx`. 

> Remarks
> 
> Identifying the current operating system is usually **not the best way to determine whether a particular operating system feature is present**. This is because the operating system may have had new features added in a redistributable DLL. **Rather than using GetVersionEx to determine the operating system platform or version number, test for the presence of the feature itself**. For more information, see Operating System Version.

 ![GTK-bug](/uploads/1cfc60444e42dc3f6e196dd3e028c9be/GTK-bug.png)

title: radio buttons are broken

title: gtk_accelerator_parse_with_keycode buffer over-run with specific input.
description:
## Steps to reproduce

 1. compile the following code:
````
#include <gtk/gtk.h>

int main(int argc, char** argv) {

	/* this one is OK */
	const char* accel0 = "<Control><Alt>>";
	gtk_accelerator_parse(accel0, NULL, NULL);

	/* this one crashes */
	const char* accel = "<Control><Alt><";
	gtk_accelerator_parse(accel, NULL, NULL);

	return 0;
}
````

using the following command: 
````
gcc `pkg-config gtk+-3.0 --cflags --libs` -fsanitize=address main.c -o gtk_test
````
It is important to have the address sanitizer.

 2. Run `gtk_test` compiled above
 3. The address sanitzer is unhappy.

Architecture: x86_64

title: Too much margin left of close button
description:
The spacing left of the close button looks a bit off, I think we should reduce it a bit.

We probably want it to be bigger than the margin on the right side to indicate that window controls are special. On the other hand, maybe we should re-evaluate whether that's even necessary since the close button is circular now (and doesn't have a border).

title: Compose sequences of GTK_MAX_COMPOSE_LEN rejected
description:
With gtk3 3.24.13-1 on Arch Linux, under X11.

To reproduce:
Edit ~/.XCompose to add a sequence of seven keys, such as the following:

`<Multi_key> <z> <w> <i> <n> <e> <s> : "🥂"`

Start a gtk3 program and observe the warning below:
```
$ gtk3-demo

(gtk3-demo:599786): Gtk-WARNING **: 23:16:10.061: The max number of sequences is 7: <Multi_key> <z> <w> <i> <n> <e> <s> : "🥂"
```

The warning printed is doubly incorrect: GTK_MAX_COMPOSE_LEN is the max *length* of a sequence, not the maximum number of sequences (as documented at https://developer.gnome.org/gtk4/stable/GtkIMContextSimple.html#GTK-MAX-COMPOSE-LEN:CAPS), and since it is the maximum, sequences of this length should be permitted rather than rejected.

It looks like the problem is a `>=` where there should be a `>` in `gtkcomposetable.c`'s `parse_compose_sequence`:

```
  if (0 == n || n >= GTK_MAX_COMPOSE_LEN)
    {
      g_warning ("The max number of sequences is %d: %s",
                 GTK_MAX_COMPOSE_LEN, line);
      return FALSE;
    }
```

title: GTK applications segfault on wayland with tablet tool input
description:
## Steps to reproduce

 1. Open GTK3 application (I've successfully managed to reproduce this with evince, remmina, nautilus and xournalpp, I'm pretty sure almost every gtk3 app will do this).
 2. Use your "tablet tool" to hover over something, if you hit/use a button to simulate a right-click it usually happens faster.
 3. Repeat 2. a few times, watch the program segfault.

## Current behavior
Using GTK applications with a "tablet tool" causes the following segfault.
```
"xournalpp" received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
#0  0x00007ffff626fda2 in wl_proxy_marshal (proxy=0x55555590d400, opcode=opcode@entry=0) at src/wayland-client.c:782
#1  0x00007ffff75c04c1 in zwp_tablet_tool_v2_set_cursor (hotspot_y=<optimized out>, hotspot_x=<optimized out>, surface=<optimized out>, serial=<optimized out>, zwp_tablet_tool_v2=<optimized out>) at ./gdk/wayland/tablet-unstable-v2-client-protocol.h:1205
(see attached backtraces for more)

```

## Expected outcome
Dont segfault when using "tablet tool".

## Version information
- GTK3 3.24.13 (from eschwartz repository with debug symbols, but extra/gtk3 does the same)
- ArchLinux
    - swaywm/wlroots
- MS Surface Go with Pen/tablet tool/stylus

## Additional information
Complete backtraces with debugging symbols:

title: gtk: gtk_gesture_get_bounding_box_center() is broken for touchpad gestures
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Try to use `gtk_gesture_get_bounding_box_center()` for touchpad pinch or swipe gestures, e.g. in the GTK gesture demo code.

## Current behavior
The function always returns the same numbers. Furthermore they are always a bit off - about 26 pixels on the X coordinate and about 60 on the Y. This seems to correlate with the `x_root` and `y_root` properties of the GdkEvent, instead of the `x` and `y`. In any case this is broken as it should return the *current* center.

## Expected outcome
The current center of the gesture is returned.

## Version information
GTK master

## Additional information
Fixed by !1257

title: New Issue following up on Issue #221 Emacs disconnects
description:
Attached is a reduced test case which was requested in the now closed
issue glib#221 - quickly sloppily hacked up from simple.c from gtk+-demos.

gtk_main is replaced by a loop which calls g_main_context_iteration.
X errors are handled via XSetIOErrorHandler and XSetErrorHandler to
handle a closed display and continue with the next
g_main_context_iteration.

To Run the test case:
gcc simple.c -Wno-deprecated -Wno-deprecated-declarations -g3 $(pkg-config gtk+-3.0 --cflags --libs ) -lX11
$ DISPLAY=:0 Xephyr :1
$ DISPLAY=:1 G_DEBUG=fatal-warnings ./a.out
kill Xephyr

The stack trace which you get from killing Xephyr is attached.

[Also featured in the code but not relevant to this bug report is the
"closed" signal which is expected from when GdkDisplay connection is
lost. This signal does not seem to fire]

title: Expects cursor theme in same location as library
description:
When playing a DVD under totem, built under jhbuild, I get:
```
Gdk-Message: 11:32:54.260: Unable to load hand2 from the cursor theme
```

But installing `adwaita-icon-theme` in jhbuild makes that error disappear.

I would expect:
- Builtin fallback (running `GDK_BACKEND=x11 CLUTTER_BACKEND=x11 jhbuild run totem` you can see the builtin X11 cursors being used)
- The `g_message` appearing only once
- the wayland library (or gtk instructing the wayland library) to know to load the cursor from another prefix (eg. respecting XDG_DATA_DIRS)

title: wayland: Excessive surface reconfiguration on every end_frame
description:
`gdk_wayland_surface_sync` does various types of surface reconfiguration, some conditionally, some not.

This function is called on `end_frame` from [gl](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/master/gdk/wayland/gdkglcontext-wayland.c#L238), [cairo](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/master/gdk/wayland/gdkcairocontext-wayland.c#L182) and [vulkan](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/master/gdk/wayland/gdkvulkancontext-wayland.c#L68) contexts.

The same problem exists in GTK 3.24, but rather than `gdk_wayland_surface_sync` and context-specific `end_frame`, it is caused by `gdk_window_impl_wayland_end_paint` and the appropriate call to `end_paint`.

The end-result of this is that every frame from these contexts lead to surface reconfiguration, as can be seen in this debug snippet from Epiphany 3.35.2:

[1408888.491]  -> wl_surface@34.commit()

```

## Applications tested

- Epiphany 3.35.2 (Devel, from gnome-nightly flatpak repo)
- Celluloid (https://github.com/celluloid-player/celluloid)
- GtkGLArea example (https://github.com/ebassi/glarea-example, tested by celluloid collaborator)

## Steps to reproduce

1. Start GL-using application from a terminal with WAYLAND_DEBUG=1
2. Interact with interact with application (e.g. use Epiphany, play in Celluloid)
3. Observe the work related to every frame in the terminal output

## Current behavior

Every or almost every frame from these applications reconfigure size hints, window geometry and input region.

## Expected outcome

No reconfiguration what-so-ever unless the window is actually reconfigured—there should only be attach, damage, frame, commit.

## Additional details

- Compositor: sway
- Distro: Arch, but all GTK applications tested through flatpak gnome-nightly

title: Performance issues with GtkListBox in GTK3
description:
Hello,

I'm using a GtkListBox which can potentially hold 3000+ rows with images, buttons, etc.
With a reasonable amount of rows, everything works as intended, but with a high amount of rows, the performance is unacceptable for a professional app to ship: scrolling barely works, and dragging the window around is a pain.

The only resource I found about this issue is [an email from 2015](https://mail.gnome.org/archives/gtk-devel-list/2015-August/msg00051.html), with a few implemntations of fixes for this issue.

Is this problem an issue to be considered? What can I do in the meantime?

Thank you

title: GtkGLArea: Should gtk_gl_area_dispose() be dropped in gtk3?
description:
gtk_gl_area_dispose() has been dropped in gtk4. See commit 34c63b8e4f5068e855283e54bf76233a4e575a59
```
glarea: Drop the dispose vfunc
    
This was causing us to leak, in the following scenario:
1) gtk_widget_destroy is called on a GL area
2) dispose is run and clears the context
3) the GL area is unrealized, but the context is already cleared,
   so we leak all the GL buffers
```
This is a nuisance in gtkmm, e.g. in the GLArea demo, which is gtkmm's version
of the corresponding demo in gtk (gtkmm#63). gtk_gl_area_dispose() is called before
the unrealize signal is emitted. When the unrealize handler is called, the GdkGLContext
has been deleted.

Is there a reason for not dropping gtk_gl_area_dispose() in gtk3?

description:

 2. compiled the example code at [Getting Started with GTK](https://developer.gnome.org/gtk4/stable/gtk-getting-started.html)  successfully

title: wayland: Multiline copy-paste contains CRLF line endings
description:
Downstream bugs in Firefox, but from what I can tell, other GTK apps also have this behavior.

- https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1547595
- https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1572104
- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/10223

I think it's possible that this only happens on non-GNOME compositors, GTK/GNOME could have some internal workaround. The report comes from KDE and I'm using Sway (so wlroots).

# Reproduction

Version information:
- Arch Linux 5.4
- wayland via sway 

Steps:
- Open firefox with `MOZ_ENABLE_WAYLAND=1`.
- Then copy any text with line endings.
- Paste it in alacritty or any non-GTK program (I use `wl-paste | hexdump -C` and look for `0A` which is `\r`).

I've confirmed that:
- It doesn't happen if I copy and paste inside GTK (I copied in firefox, created a new gist with the text contents, then pulled the file).
- It doesn't happen in Xwayland if I start firefox without the above flag.
_ I wasn't able to confirm if this also happens on X11 because I run sway which is wayland-only

# Analysis

I've traced out the issue a bit. On paste, firefox calls `gtk_selection_data_set_text` with proper line endings `\n`:
- https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/file/61ec58edfd13861591d5cd4b6387de92b35f23e3/widget/gtk/nsClipboard.cpp#l520

I've confirmed that GTK calls the `gtk_selection_set_text_plain` branch:
- https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/88da95d921f902ee3599ac39b26553a7c4eeb2fa/gtk/gtkselection.c#L683

GTK for some reason normalizes the line endings to CRLF internally so when reading the raw clipboard data, CRLF will be present:
- https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/88da95d921f902ee3599ac39b26553a7c4eeb2fa/gtk/gtkselection.c#L555



I think in some code uses `selection_get_text_plain` which normalizes back to LF when reading.
- https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/88da95d921f902ee3599ac39b26553a7c4eeb2fa/gtk/gtkselection.c#L629

There's a whole bunch of code around normalization in `gdkselection-x11`:
- https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/88da95d921f902ee3599ac39b26553a7c4eeb2fa/gdk/x11/gdkselection-x11.c#L408

Some of that was copied into `gdkselection-wayland`, but that seems to mainly run on Xwayland which might explain why it doesn't break when firefox is ran via Xwayland.
- https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/88da95d921f902ee3599ac39b26553a7c4eeb2fa/gdk/wayland/gdkselection-wayland.c#L128

# Fix

GTK should either stop doing the `normalize_to_lf`/`normalize_to_crlf` dance internally, or the `gdkselection-wayland` code needs expanding to fix paste for Wayland as well, not just Xwayland. I might be able to write a patch if you provide some guidance on what the correct solution is.

title: GDKCursor name_fallback is unfortunate and not easy to workaround.
description:
The fallback name map [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/336d652be547b7548dc3e6b6760c318768998dd7/gdk/x11/gdkcursor-x11.c#L108) and on the equivalent wayland code, is a bit unfortunate, since it means that `zoom-in` icons, for example, end up displaying the normal icon, if the theme doesn't have that icon present.

This is the case for example for the default Ubuntu cursor theme, which is kind of annoying.

This causes issues with Firefox, as Firefox has its own set of fallback icons to use that are better than the left pointer.

There's a Firefox issue tracking it in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1428755.

I can work around it, on X11, by calling into X directly (this is on gtk3): https://phabricator.services.mozilla.com/D56361. However on wayland that becomes much harder.

I see that the code for current trunk has changed substantially, and you need to provide the fallback cursor eagerly. That's alright, but unless I'm misreading the code, the fallback cursor still gets checked only _after_ the fallback name, so it still wouldn't work for our purposes...

Is there a way to provide an API to not use the name fallback, or something of that sort?

title: Newer Windows 10 emoji picker doesn't work (support new Windows 10 Emoji Panel)
description:
## Steps to reproduce

 1. Start "Entry Buffer" from gtk3-demo.
 2. Focus on the entry widget.
 3. Open Win 10 emoji picker (by pressing `Win + ;` or `Win + .`).
 4. Select any emoji.

## Current behavior

The selected emoji doesn't appear in the entry widget. The following warnings appear in the terminal:

```
(gtk3-demo.exe:8324): Gtk-CRITICAL **: 07:20:09.542: gtk_im_context_simple_commit_char: assertion 'g_unichar_validate (ch)' failed

(gtk3-demo.exe:8324): Gtk-CRITICAL **: 07:20:09.542: gtk_im_context_simple_commit_char: assertion 'g_unichar_validate (ch)' failed
```

## Expected outcome

Emojis should appear in the active entry widget.

## Version information

- Windows 10 1909
- mingw-w64-x86_64-gtk3 3.24.13-1

title: Usage of GtkStack comes with a significant performance hit
description:
In upcoming Inkscape 1.0 we use a (homogeneous) GtkStack to implement the toolbar (children are exchanged depending on the active tool).

Recently I've discovered this is the source of very bad performance when the main window goes into backdrop (or returns into foreground). Transitions appear very unsmooth (basically two "steps" are rendered) and the user interface becomes unresponsive during that time (I'd estimate up to one second).

Now I've made an attempt to set the GtkStack to inhomogeneous (which helps a bit) but is still significantly worse than simply wrapping the toolbar widgets directly into their parent and showing/hiding them manually or (I guess that's more or less equivalent) using a GtkSizeGroup (which was used before we switches do GtkStack).

In summary:
* GtkStack (homogeneous) - very bad performance hit
* GtkStack (inhomogeneous) - performance hit
* GtkSizeGroup - performance OK
* Children directly wrapped into parent container - performance OK

It seems there's something wrong with GtkStack that causes bad performance?  
From my understanding when setting the stack not to be homogeneous it should not cause any overhead compared to GtkSizeGroup or any other container?

---

For reference this was observed on Windows 10 with (mingw-w64-x86_64-gtk3 3.24.13-1)

Downstream issue: https://gitlab.com/inkscape/inkscape/issues/509

title: Support CSS variables
description:
CSS variables may allow the user customize the theme / set an accent color (without a Sass compiler).

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Using_CSS_custom_properties

title: CI: Run tests in valgrind
description:
Matthias recently did a bunch of leak fixing in my tests and I was slightly embarrassed about committing such leaky code and not having done that work myself.  
That's when I thought about CI and its job being to save me from embarrassment, so can we make it run tests under valgrind or some other form of memory leak detection?

I guess the main problem is that GDK can't really unref() displays, but at least the tests that don't need a display (CSS parser, listmodels, ...) could be made to run that way?

title: criticals when toggling logging checkbuttons
GtkImage should have a way of diagnosing missing images
description:
GtkImage centralizes image loading in [`load_scalable_with_loader`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/e4b8481d/gtk/gtkimage.c#L585).  When that function fails to load the image, it just returns NULL and the two callers set the image to an icon name `image-missing`, which shows up visually.

However, there is no way to diagnose what went wrong, as `load_scalable_with_loader` ignores all errors.

I'd like to have a sensible way to do present this information.  Apart from using a `GError` everywhere inside that function, there are some options:

* At the exit points of that function, simply `g_message()` with the error message.
* Add a `GtkDebugFlag` just for that, and `GTK_NOTE(IMAGE, g_message(...))` instead.

From a distro's viewpoint, the first one is more direct, and it allows me to get debug information from users without an extra step and inconvenience to the users.  The second one is probably more GTK-ish, but more inconvenient for users.

Please take your pick and I'll submit a MR :)

title: Enhancement: Add gtk_tree_model_set_value() / gtk_tree_model_set() method
description:
This enhancement request aims to make it easier for the user to change a value "inside" a GtkTreeModel.
Currently I feel a real challenge to accomplish (especially for novices) "making a cell editable". There is already a lot of "knowledge noise" through Renderer and the function signature of current value set functions.

Currently Situation:
====================
It is very difficult to change the value of a cell through GtkTreeModel: 
The user must use GtkTreeStore methods or GtkListStore methods to change values. In case of GtkTreeModelSorted, things get even more difficult. The necessity for differentiation results in the uselessness of the GtkTreeModel interface, as it cannot be used universally.



Suggestion:
===========
Provide the following function:
```
void
gtk_tree_model_set (GtkTreeModel *tree_store,
                    GtkTreeIter *iter,
                    ...);
```

Implementation:
===============

- GtkListStore already has gtk_list_store_set()
- GtkTreeStore already has gtk_tree_store_set()
- GtkTreeModelSort has no implementation, yet. It might look like the following:
  ```
    GtkTreeModelSort * model_sorted = GTK_TREE_MODEL_SORT(p_model_sorted);
		    
    GtkTreeIter iter_sortedModel;
    gtk_tree_model_get_iter_from_string((GtkTreeModel*)model_sorted,
                  &iter_sortedModel, path_string);  		

    GtkListStore * model_raw;		
    model_raw = GTK_LIST_STORE(gtk_tree_model_sort_get_model(model_sorted));

    GtkTreeIter iter_rawModel;
    gtk_tree_model_sort_convert_iter_to_child_iter(model_sorted, &iter_rawModel, &iter_sortedModel);


    gtk_list_store_set(model_raw, &iter_rawModel,
            					LIST_COL_NAME, new_text, -1);
  ```

- Of course, the respective function should be called through gtk_tree_model_set. 


Remark:
=======
Changing the signature of the callback on "edited" to include a direct link to the cell content, which could then be changed directly, would of course be a much better solution. I did not suggest that one, as I expect it to be much harder to implement and therefore less likely to be implemented.

title: Menus don't close on click when opening then closing again quickly.
description:
Traditional menus don't respond to the click to close them if it happens shortly after they were opened.

Examples:
- If I click on "File" then click again in the same place to close the "File" menu shortly after it was opened.
- If I click on "File" then move to "Edit" then click again to close the menu shortly after moving to "Edit".

This problem occurs when:
- A user opens a menu but changes their mind so tries to close the menu by clicking in the same place again.
- A user is looking through the menus and then decides what they are looking for isn't there so tries to close the menu.

Additional information:

GTK+3 version: 3.24.13

title: Enhancement: Interchange sort indicator icons
description:
With this enhancement request I'm trying to suggest a more intuitive representation of the sort indicator items (▼,▲) for `GtkTreeView`s.

Current Situation
==================
*  GTK_SORT_ASCENDING  has the icon ▼ 
*  GTK_SORT_DESCENDING has the icon ▲ 

Suggestion
===========
Inverse the icons:
*  GTK_SORT_ASCENDING  has the icon ▲
*  GTK_SORT_DESCENDING has the icon ▼


Logic behind this suggestion
=============================
Ascending order means "from low to high" (like "1,2,3,..." or "a,b,c,..."). In other words: "from a small value to a high value". This logic is represented by this symbol: ▲. The triangles smallest part is in the top. The triangles biggest part is in the bottom. So a "1" would be in the top, a "100" would be in the bottom.

Remarks
=======
I guess the current behaviour is inherited from arrow symbols, where "↓" is "ascending" and  "↑" is "descending". This made perfect sense. However, then the strokes where probably removed and the triangle was, what's left. However, not being an arrow inverts the logic (as of my point of view).

title: GtkFileChooserDialog Unexpectedly Overwrites Another File
description:
## Steps to reproduce

 1. You have two files named `file1.txt` and `file2.txt` in the same directory.
 2. Open an editor (for example, *gedit*), type something, then press `Save`, so a `GtkFileChooserDialog` (save dialog) pops up.
 3. In this dialog, choose `file1.txt`, and press *Save*. So it will ask you whether you want to overwrite `file1.txt`.
 4. Choose `Replace`, **and immediately click on `file2.txt`** before the dialog disappears.
 5. Now, `file2.txt` is overwritten, instead of `file1.txt`.

<!--
  You should try and reproduce with the demos applications available
  under the `demos` directory, or the test programs in the `tests` directory.
  Alternatively, please attach a *small and self-contained* example
  *written in C* that exhibits the issue.
-->

## Current behavior

  `GtkFileChooserDialog` allows a user to choose another file even after he clicks `Replace` button, which results in the application overwriting another file unexpectedly, causing data loss.


## Expected outcome

  **After a user clicks on `Replace` button, `GtkFileChooserDialog` should prevent the user from choosing another file in the list.** Today I "double clicked" the mouse on the `Replace` button, then it overwrote another file unexpectedly and I lost all my data in it.


## Version information
<!--
 - Which version of GTK you are using
 - What operating system and version
  - For Linux, which distribution
 - If you built GTK yourself, the list of options used to configure the build
-->
GTK version: 3-3.24.11

OS: Fedora 30

GNOME version: 3.32.2

 - Please report any warning or message printed on the terminal
-->

title: dedicated window decoration library
description:
For Wayland applications that would like to use GTK-styled window decorations without depending on full GTK, it would be very useful to separate the basic decoration functionality into a dedicated library. This should only concern the default window decoration and its functionality (minimise, maximise, close) as shown by mutter on X11/Xwayland.

Such a small and dedicated library would be very helpful to applications that do not want to depend on a full toolkit for drawing CSD on Wayland, and which are usually not concerned with drawing window decoration and its logic on other platforms like Windows, macOS or Android.
Examples of such projects are SDL, GLFW, and mpv, since these projects draw to raw buffers or use OpenGL directly.

Projects like [libdecoration](https://gitlab.gnome.org/jadahl/libdecoration) attempt to support projects with CSD on Wayland, but would also depend on a GTK-decorations library to match the style as found in original GTK applications.

Furthermore, GTK itself could depend on such a GTK-decoration library to make sure that GTK as a toolkit, applications that use this GTK-decoration library and applications that use the library via libdecoration, would all look the same and integrate well.

title: macOS: GDL dialog docking broken with 3.24
description:
## Steps to reproduce

 1. Compile gtk-3-22 and gtk-3-24 on macOS (Quartz backend)
 2. Compile [gdl](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gdl) with both versions
 3. Run `./gdl/test-dock`
 4. Drag out `Item #6`

## Current behavior

- With gtk-3-24: Drag operation gets stuck
- With gtk-3-22: Works as expected, `Item #6` detaches to a new window

## Expected outcome

gtk-3-24 works like gtk-3-22

## Version information

- macOS 10.14.6
- MacPorts environment
  - `gtk3 @3.22.30_1+quartz`
  - `gtk3 @3.24.12_0+quartz`
  - Also compiled from source with `--enable-quartz-backend` and without any extra patches
    - gtk-3-24 branch (61d7700c17)
    - gtk-3-22 branch (69ddfcf1ed)

## Additional information

- Affects Inkscape: https://gitlab.com/inkscape/inkscape/issues/410

title: Documentation: Enhancement: remove min width from styling
description:
Actual:
In the documentation [(exampleLink)](https://developer.gnome.org/gtk3/unstable/GtkTreeModel.html) there seems to be a (big) min-width set. 

Expected / Suggestion: 
- No min-width at all (best).
OR
- Very small min-width

Reason for Suggestion:
- Most of the documentation is free text. I don't see a reason to setup a min width.
- Regarding my setup: I'm forced to cover 60% of my (single screen) with the documentation or scroll around to read.

title: Text-shadow could be too strong
description:
1) Everywhere inside adwaita-dark

With current text shadow:

![image_2019-11-04_13-10-22](/uploads/f337419abdf5e6321d218e580050849e/image_2019-11-04_13-10-22.png)
![image](/uploads/07d2efa7697959cd8db9ae1649bd8349/image.png)
![image](/uploads/5f1d71d1677ae0f588ecef40107de3ba/image.png)

Without the current text shadow:

![image_2019-11-04_13-10-41](/uploads/64fad95e7e564485358ed6a7c902dd0e/image_2019-11-04_13-10-41.png)
![image](/uploads/9396268589a75ee09ee05578d12551c5/image.png)

2) For .suggested-action and .destructive-action buttons in both the dark and the light theme

With the current text shadow:

![image_2019-11-04_11-52-55](/uploads/bff723a80866dfa671af67ce94a93dae/image_2019-11-04_11-52-55.png)

![image_2019-11-04_11-56-41](/uploads/99f5515ec577f34c7fca56a56d7dd2eb/image_2019-11-04_11-56-41.png)

Without:

![image](/uploads/5e9789e5b007f46817df0af85b5bac9f/image.png)
![image](/uploads/6dea8da1329b23e4260e1e9c7a5c6b80/image.png)
![image](/uploads/e24595fbb1c6b55099d7db5a63c352ee/image.png)
![image](/uploads/987034ad70ba2639704df468a4c295e4/image.png)

- IMHO this gives text and unproportionally heavy depth compared to the general look of the theme
- it somehow gives the whole theme a little retro vibe
- sometimes it makes the text look blurry, I think text should be sharp and clear, like in a very well printed book or magazine

Could we trim it down to an absolute minimum needed for good legibility?

title: Change Bluetoooth device names so you can more easily use multiple devices with the same generic name?
description:
Hi,

I have several pairs of Sony MDR-1000X bluetooth headphones, which I have identifying colors and places they go that identify them to me.  I take my laptop to different locations, and want to connect the correct headphones to the laptop and I'm not sure which device to connect with, because I can't remember them by the MAC address.  I followed the instructions here:
https://elementaryos.stackexchange.com/questions/2650/how-can-i-change-the-names-of-paired-connected-remote-bluetooth-devices
but it seems that something is changing the name, when the headphones are connected, back to the generic name.  I don't know if this is gnome-settings or something further down the stack.  It would be really nice if you could change the name in gnome-settings and have it stay.  My android phone allows this very nicely. 

Thanks,

Rob

title: feature request: support multiple keybindings for media keys
description:
Problem: two keyboards, one without media keys, so some combo required for it. Lets say, Super+somekey maps to XF86AudioMute.  It is possible with XKB, but required functionality is not avaliable in Wayland (RedirectKey with clearMods [because for Gnome XF86AudioMute != Mod4+XF86AudioMute]).

Easy solution: two keybindings (Super+somekey, XF86AudioMute) for one function (mute sound)

title: [Enhancement] [Thinkpad x1 Yoga] No OSD is shown when 'Fn + D'  key is pressed
description:
OSD is not displayed when user presses 'Fn + D' in thinkpad X1 yoga . 
Functionality of this key is "e-privacy" and its not there in all systems. thinkpad X1 yoga has this functionality.  
Functionality wise its working Ok in ubuntu 18.04 which i am using but only OSD is not displayed . 
Same behavior observerd in ubuntu 19.10 and Gnome-shell version 3.34.1
Just for information - In windows ,OSD is getting displayed. i have attached screenshot when e-privacy is On/OFF as i can see in windows. Does this behavior is handled in gnome-settings-daemon ? is it Ok to raise it as Improvement here? 
![e-privacy_off](/uploads/e66053c07d60b8887177f9c47ecd313e/e-privacy_off.png)

![e-privacy_on](/uploads/8ee6454ff67a8dfb233ef7a6bcfd87aa/e-privacy_on.png) ,

/label \~"1. Enhancement"

title: Typo in translatable string: implemeting
description:
In `gxml/StreamReader.vala` is a string containing `is not implemeting GXml.Object interface`.

Here `implemeting` should be `implementing`.

title: Non-functional, physically not existing printers listed; reappears after deletion
description:
Fedora 31, g-c-c 3.34.2

I have an HP Color LaserJet 254nw which correctly appears in the g-c-c printer list, after being connected to the pc (e.g. printer and pc are in same network).  
But besides that, there is always another printer with has nearly the same name but an additional weird number as a suffix:  
![Screenshot_from_2019-12-26_22-09-02](/uploads/063f797fd856d0781c2ec67ddcda0c97/Screenshot_from_2019-12-26_22-09-02.png)

The same printer does not show up in hplip or the cups web interface:  
![image](/uploads/93ba888f9cc3b3c6b4bc5466d25dcb2e/image.png)
![Screenshot_from_2019-12-26_23-49-58](/uploads/bf2290a0265fbd0af875488abdf08da2/Screenshot_from_2019-12-26_23-49-58.png)

This additional printer is completely useless, as it does not work at all (it can not print, has no printing options...) and always reappears after some time when you delete it from g-c-c.

title: GNOME-Control-Center fails to build with Flatpak-builder - network-manager-applet

will be removed. Read it carefully before submitting this issue.

title: "Change password" dialog autofills password confirmation when generating a new password
description:
When autogenerating a password in Details->Users, the `Confirm New Password` field is filled out automatically. When the password is generated by the computer, I believe the user should be required to confirm the new password by having to enter the password as well.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Open GNOME Settings
2. Select Details
3. Select Users
4. Unlock Users page
5. Select the password box
6. Enter current password correctly
7. Select Generate Password icon in "New Password" field
8. See that the "Confirm New Password" box has been filled out.


Note: This issue was originally created downstream here: https://github.com/pop-os/pop/issues/793

Fedora 31, gnome-control-center 3.34.2

2. Turn on Bluetooth using your preferred way

title: Default Application selector offers only "Web", even though Chromium is installed
description:
I'm having trouble setting the default/preferred browser to Chromium.
  • Chromium is installed.
  • Chromium thinks it is the default browser.
  • xdg-mime thinks Chromium is the default browser.
  • Gnome Control Center shows "Web" as the default browser.
  • Gnome Control Center's selector doesn't offer Chromium as an option.
  • When I press the /org/gnome/settings-daemon/plugins/media-keys/www keyboard shortcut, Web (epiphany) is launched. I would like this to launch Chromium.
  • Gnome Control Center's "application" page for Chromium doesn't contain the "default handler" control described in #450.
``` $ xdg-mime query default x-scheme-handler/http chromium-browser.desktop ``` ![web-just-web](/uploads/335bf571922466976c8dfd12a191c5bb/web-just-web.gif) ![chrome-thinks-it-is-default](/uploads/38b4347ece8a8baa9cc639091e765f86/chrome-thinks-it-is-default.png) Note: This is on [NixOS](https://nixos.org/nixos), which sometimes puts files in different places than normal.

title: Media Sharing doesn't explain what it actually enables
description:
The "Media Sharing" dialog doesn't explain what it actually enables. I believe it should also show the following information.

* What protocol exactly? (UPnP/DLNA)
* How to Access this media from other devices
* Whether accessing the media will require a password

title: Disabling notification not repsected by some applications
description:
Disabling the notifications in `Applications` --> `AppName` --> `Notifications` is not respected by some applications. An example for this is Spotify.  
Furthermore, both locations where you can edit the notification settings show different applications for which you can change permissions. This might have the same root cause. See:  
![Screenshot_from_2019-12-14_10-02-24](/uploads/98d34cc279cfaccc67f5f5f987a76cf7/Screenshot_from_2019-12-14_10-02-24.png)  
![Screenshot_from_2019-12-14_10-01-39](/uploads/f8d49f774a2dbbad0ee9c9b3a4cb72d9/Screenshot_from_2019-12-14_10-01-39.png)

Steps to reproduce:

1. Install Spotify flatpak
2. Flip the switch in `Applications` --> `Spotify` --> `Notifications` to disable Spotifys notifications
3. Start Spotify
4. Get a notification when the song changes

title: Accessibility panel: Add a switch for the "Locate pointer" feature
description: The "Pointer location" feature (`org.gnome.desktop.interface locate-pointer`) is currently hidden away in gnome-tweaks. It would be much more useful if it were hidden away among the other accessibility settings instead – for example, next to "Seeing / Cursor size" would be a logical place.

title: Add test dialog for microphones
description:
It would be nice to have a "Test" dialog for input devices (i.e. microphones) similarly to what we have currently for output devices. The idea is to enable PulseAudio Loopback Device so one can check what is heard. I use [PulseAudio Loopback Device](https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/954/pulseaudio-loopback-device/) extension for this purpose currently but would be nice to have this embedded.

/cc @aday

title: [RFE] Apply night light on login screen
description:
Currently, it is very disruptive that the night light is not applied to the login screen. This is especially visible when changing users, logging out or logging in. 
It would be helpful if the night light would be applied to the login screen just as it is to the regular session.

title: No thumbnail for slideshow xml if files are in relative paths to my home directory
description:
I made a slideshow xml like:
```
<background>
  <static>
    <duration>60</duration>
    <file>Pictures/mybackground/image-0.png</file>
  </static>
           ....................
</background>
```
And I added an background properties xml file in `.local/share/gnome-background-properties`
to register the slideshow xml. However, in GNOME settings, it appeared as solid color,
not as an image thumbnail. But setting the wallpaper to it is working.

If I replace the file paths with absolute paths, its thumbnail shows up.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Make a slideshow background xml with file paths relative to your home directory
2. Add an xml file in `.local/share/gnome-background-properties`
3. Open GNOME Settings
4. Find its thumbnail

In addition, differently from https://help.ubuntu.com/community/SlideshowWallpapers,
relative filename paths in background properties xml files are not working.

GNOME version 3.34.2
Arch Linux

title: Move "Default Applications" from "Details" to "Applications" screen
description:
# Current problems
<!--

For example:
* User cannot use the keyboard to perform most common actions
or
* User cannot see documents from cloud services
-->
"Default Applications" is not in "Applications" section.

# Goals & use cases
<!--
What are the use cases that this proposal will cover? What are the end goals?

For example:
* User needs to share a file with their friends.
or
* It should be easy to edit a picture within the app.
-->
It would be easier for a user to set the "Default Applications".

# Requirements
<!--


For example:
* Work on small form factors and touch
or
* Use the Meson build system and integrate with it
-->
Move "Default Applications" to "Applications" screen.

# Relevant art
<!--
Is there any product that has implemented something similar? Put links to other
projects, pictures, links to other code, etc.
-->
none

# Proposal & plan
<!-- What's the solution and how should be achieved? It can be split in smaller
tasks of minimum change, so they can be delivered across several releases. -->
Move "Default Applications" to "Applications" screen.

title: Allow remote files in “Select a file...” chooser
description:
It currently only supports local files, but we should be able to load files from “remote locations”, such as smb:, ssh:, or gphoto2: for cameras.

- [ ] In `panels/user-accounts/cc-avatar-chooser.c`'s `cc_avatar_chooser_select_file`, make sure that the local-only property is off

- [ ] In `file_chooser_response`, use `gtk_file_chooser_get_uri()`, instead of `get_filename()`, create a GFile from it, and get a path using `g_file_get_path()`. This will get you a local path, as if it were on the local filesystem, through fuse.

title: Ability to rename (paired) Bluetooth devices
description:
Currently (GNOME 3.34.1), the Bluetooth panel presents the user with a list of connected or available Bluetooth devices, using its name to identify each of them. When a bluetooth device is connected, you can click on it in the Bluetooth panel and it will show this window:

![Bluetooth device information window](/uploads/d75107097f9fa3c01a24fc3bc7d6d067/bluetooth-rename.png)

It would be nice to have the ability, once a Bluetooth device is paired, to change its name.

Rationale:

My wife and I both own a pair of identical Bluetooth earphones (same brand, same model). I ended up pairing both to my laptop. Now, when I turn one pair on, I have no idea which one is supposed to get connected or not.

On my Android smartphone, I paired both, but there is a feature to rename the devices, so I modified their name to know which one I want to connect easily.

For the UI, I guess a simple text field under "Address" (in the above screenshot) would be enough.

Thank you!

title: Network link speed reported is wrong
description:
Fedora 31, gnome-control-center 3.34.2

I have a Dell XPS 9370 which has a built in `Qualcomm Atheros QCA6174 802.11ac Wireless Network Adapter (rev 32)` wifi network adapter.  
When connecting to any wifi network, g-c-c always reports a link speed of 1 Mb/s. Nevertheless, the actual network speed is way higher, see the following example:  
![Screenshot_from_2019-12-03_22-12-57](/uploads/aec30ac8dfbc5fbf4a2d03cd96b96e01/Screenshot_from_2019-12-03_22-12-57.png)

title: Time & Date: avoid dropdown for time format setting
description:
[Dropdowns should be avoided when possible](https://www.lukew.com/ff/entry.asp?1950), and in this case replacing it with a stack switcher looks doable:

![image](/uploads/e3234704dfdf60f9d94f0f6d634afb89/image.png)

title: add "Run in background" to the System integration section
description:
This should use the background table in the flatpak permission store - the flatpak portals now monitor applications that are running without open windows ("in the background"), and notify the user about that. This permission is used in deciding whether the app is allowed to run in the background or now, and having a switch in the application panel to change it would be very valuable. One reason is that I want the default action of the notification to open this settings panel, which only makes sense if the "run in background" permission is shown.

We can also consider adding a "Start at login" switch. The portal lets applications request that as well, and it works by creating an autostart file for the application, so that would be what the switch would control - whether the autostart file is there or not.

title: Add way to change audio output (speakers vs headphones) on a per application basis
description:
As far as I know, it is not possible to change the audio output on a per application basis from anywhere in gnome-shell. An external application (e.g. pavucontrol) is required. 

Such a normal task, however, shouldn't require third party applications. It is unreasonable to think that a normal user would want to have Spotify on his speakers and a Discord call in his earbuds? As a matter of fact, everyone else has this feature built-in (e.g. Windows, OSX, Plasma, don't know about MATE, XFCE and LXQt). But why should gnome require an external application/extension? 

My suggestion is to add a dropdown in the sound settings or expand the functionality provided by the user-menu volume indicator: maybe instead of muting on click, something kind of stupid in my opinion, it would expand to a sub menu, [like this extension](https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/906/sound-output-device-chooser/).

![audio-mockup](/uploads/3352f7258832bc237aa64c1e381a3e59/audio-mockup.png)

title: Searching for language+region in language selector doesn’t work
description:
This might be outmoded by, or complementary to, #202 (which proposes a redesign of this dialogue).

Currently (GNOME 3.34, F31), clicking the vertical 3 dots at the bottom of the list allows you to search it. However, searching by the text which is in each entry doesn’t work: if I search for ‘English’, I get a lot of results (one for each English-speaking region), but if I then include the region in my search term, I get no results.

Searching for the region by itself (‘Canada’ in the example below) seems to bring up the right results for that.

See the screenshots below.

This happens in the language selector in ‘Region & Language’ and also in ‘Users’ (I guess they’re the same widget).

![Screenshot_from_2019-11-28_13-37-45](/uploads/49e12c5f30be2331dea534bb8377894c/Screenshot_from_2019-11-28_13-37-45.png)
![Screenshot_from_2019-11-28_13-37-51](/uploads/4983f982b152b769ff18e8dfdb462088/Screenshot_from_2019-11-28_13-37-51.png)

title: GLib-2.0.gir is in an architecture-independent location, but is architecture-dependent
description:
GLib-2.0.gir contains some architecture-dependent macros and types:

* `SEARCHPATH_SEPARATOR`, `SEARCHPATH_SEPARATOR_S`, `Pid` (Unix vs. Windows)
* `SIZEOF_LONG`, `SIZEOF_SIZE_T`, `SIZEOF_SSIZE_T`, `SIZEOF_VOID_P`, `VA_COPY_AS_ARRAY` (C type/calling convention facts)
* `SYSDEF_AF_INET`, `SYSDEF_MSG_DONTROUTE` etc. (kernel ABI facts)
* `GINT16_FORMAT`, `GINT16_MODIFIER` etc. (facts about printf)

However, it is installed in `${datadir}`, the directory hierarchy for architecture-independent files (as opposed to `${libdir}`, the directory hierarchy for architecture-dependent files).

This means in particular that if you're cross-compiling, or mixing architectures on one system with Red-Hat-style biarch (lib, lib64) or Debian-style multiarch (lib/i386-linux-gnu, lib/x86_64-linux-gnu), then the copy of GLib-2.0.gir in /usr/share is likely to contain facts that are wrong for either the host (cross) architecture or the build (native) architecture.

The typelib compiled from the XML does not have this problem: it is installed in `${libdir}/girepository-1.0`, which is for example `.../lib64/...` on Red-Hat-style systems or `.../lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/...` on Debian-style systems.

Possible solutions include:

* Remove these macros and types from the GIR XML. They're probably uninteresting to introspected languages like JavaScript and Python anyway (although they are likely to be more interesting to languages that generate architecture-dependent code, like Vala, and perhaps to documentation tools).

* Remove these macros' and types' values and source positions from the GIR XML, but keep the fact that they exist, and their C names.

* Introduce a new architecture-dependent location for GIR XML (probably the same place as typelibs: `${GI_TYPELIB_PATH}`, defaulting to `${libdir}/girepository-1.0`), move GLib's GIR XML there, and teach consumers of this information to load from there in addition to `${XDG_DATA_DIRS}/gir-1.0`.

* Keep the majority of GLib's GIR XML in `${datadir}`, but have some way to offload the architecture-dependent parts to a separate file in `${libdir}/girepository-1.0` or similar.

title: meson: add version checks for bison and flex
description: Turns out 3eb5b8b1051d10 doesn't work with the system bison on macOS 10.13 and I had to install it from homebrew instead. It would be nice if we'd have some version checks in meson. google tells me that gstreamer has something like this already.

title: Document how to update glib GIR
description:
and others? But where? In the HACKING file would make the most sense.

```sh
$ git clone https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib.git
$ meson _build
$ ninja -C _build
$ ./misc/update-glib-annotations.py glib/
```

title: Don't add warnings by hand in meson file
description:
```sh
$ meson --buildtype debug --fatal-meson-warnings _build
[...]
WARNING: Consider using the builtin warning_level option instead of adding warning flags by hand.

meson.build:73:0: ERROR: Fatal warnings enabled, aborting
```

title: Support alternate ways to specify GTest modes
description:
Currently, the only way to activate other GTest modes (slow, thorough, etc) is using a command line argument to the test runner. This makes it difficult when integrating with meson's test support and other non-GTest based tests exist (e.g. when validating desktop and appdata files as tests, as is a common pattern in GNOME apps now), since you can't easily specify which tests should receive the extra command line arguments and which should not. In particular, I'd like quick tests to be the default under development and thorough tests to be the default under CI.

An easy way to do this would be to take notice of a `G_TEST_MODE` or similar environment variable and use that as the default mode if set. It would be trivial then to make thorough tests the default when run under CI.

title: gsettings(1): Describe the filesystem location where settings are stored
description:
The gsettings(1) manual page should describe the filesystem location where settings are stored.

After some research I found that they are stored in a binary file, `.config/dconf/user`.

Knowing this location will be helpful to users who are interested in backing up their GTK settings or transferring them from one computer to another.

Thank you.

description:

title: Warn/error when passing void returning function pointer to G_SOURCE_FUNC macro
description:
So, I ran after a bug earlier today where a void function was passed to `g_timeout_add`. Quite a pain, as it resulted in a fun stack corruption …

Anyway, it would not have helped here, because it was a direct cast using `(GSourceFunc)`, but I was contemplating whether one could warn a bit more while not making the cast completely useless.

I came up with
```
#define G_SOURCE_FUNC(f) ((void) ((glong) (__typeof__((f)())) 0), (GSourceFunc) (void (*)(void)) (f))
```
Which uses the GCC extension `typeof` to causes a compile time error for functions that return `void`.

i.e. if a void function is passed, you will get: `error: invalid use of void expression` pointing to the `(glong)` cast. For functions returning `char`, `int` or `void*` no warning is printed.

Unfortunately, it will completely break for non-function pointers. And throwing an error is probably also too extreme.

----

So, feel free to just ignore this issue and close the bug again :)

title: A typo in the comment of `g_settings_schema_get_path`: threfore -> therefore
description:
See [this line on `master`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/blob/master/gio/gsettingsschema.c#L992). The related code is quoted below:

```c
/**
 * g_settings_schema_get_path:
 * @schema: a #GSettingsSchema
 *
 * Gets the path associated with @schema, or %NULL.
 *
 * Schemas may be single-instance or relocatable.  Single-instance
 * schemas correspond to exactly one set of keys in the backend
 * database: those located at the path returned by this function.
 *
 * Relocatable schemas can be referenced by other schemas and can
 * threfore describe multiple sets of keys at different locations.  For
 * relocatable schemas, this function will return %NULL.
 *
 * Returns: (transfer none): the path of the schema, or %NULL
 *
 * Since: 2.32
 **/
const gchar *
g_settings_schema_get_path (GSettingsSchema *schema)
{
  return schema->path;
}
```

The word `threfore` should be `therefore`.

title: Documentation for e.g. g_variant_get
description:
Hi,

The glib website [1] suggested filing an issue for documentation issues, so here goes.

It's not clear to me from the documentation for e.g. g_variant_get() [2] how one can pass "dummy" parameters for any aspect of the variant extraction which the user is not actually interested in.

For example, imagine a format string of the type "(&sa{sv}as)" (as used by certain Bluez messages over DBus). If I wish to extract the first and second elements of the tuple, but ignore the third, how might I accomplish this? Is it possible to simply pass a NULL destination for the third element to instruct the function to ignore it, e.g.:

```
const gchar *elem_one;
GVariantIter elem_two;

g_variant_get(params, "(&sa{sv}as)", &elem_one, &elem_two, NULL);
```

The documentation does not indicate what happens with a NULL parameter. Is this the correct way to approach this issue? If so, can the documentation be updated?

Thanks,

John.

[1] https://developer.gnome.org/glib/stable/glib-resources.html

[2] https://developer.gnome.org/glib/stable/glib-GVariant.html#g-variant-get

title: notify_lock taken three times in GObject::notify; racy
description:
In `g_object_notify_by_spec_internal()`, the `notify_lock` is taken and released three times in the `nqueue != NULL` code path, once by each of `g_object_notify_queue_freeze()`, `g_object_notify_queue_add()` and `g_object_notify_queue_thaw()`. It’s possible that another thread could emit `GObject::notify`, or freeze/thaw the notify queue, between those locks being held, and hence mess up the emissions.

The locks should be combined and a unit test added (if a relevant one doesn’t exist already).

title: Implement “warning: metered connection” dialogue when manually checking for updates
description:
Implement the “warning: metered connection” dialogue from the top of https://gitlab.gnome.org/Teams/Design/software-mockups/blob/master/updates-dialogs.png, which will be shown when the user’s on a metered connection and clicks on the ‘update’ button to manually check for updates.

This is a follow-up to https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/merge_requests/339#note_671760.

title: Upgrades erroneously marked as downgrades
description:
I've seen gnome-software list upgrades as downgrades multiple times, as far as I can remember always of this form: 

![image](/uploads/b22f6bbf110ae8171f0b19763869d69b/image.png)

The old version has a [debian_revision](https://www.debian.org/doc/debian-policy/ch-controlfields.html#version) with two numeric parts, and the new has just one. Because of this it seems it sees the new version as a lower version than the old, and calls it a downgrade. Neither apt nor `appstreamcli compare-versions` call this a downgrade. 

I've found cb81a2931b9ddaaf8e04e43c1323eb927b176d9e pointing to an earlier issue with version sorting. 

I'm running Debian bullseye, I have `gnome-software` version `3.30.6-5+b1`, and `libappstream-glib8` version `0.7.16-1`. I do however see the Debian package requires `libappstream-glib8 (>= 0.7.10)`. That could possibly mean it's built with a version without `as_utils_vercmp_full`, which could explain this behavior.

title: Licence 'unknown' instead of 'privative' for .deb packages
description:
Context:
[Jami](https://jami.net/) is an open source distributed alternative to Skype, We distribute our packages directly from our site web and many distributions include our software.

When users download our .deb packages for Debian, Ubuntu, Trisquel ... and they click then gnome-sofware take over and help users to Install our package but it says that our package have a **Privative Licence**

![gnome-sofware-jami-deb](/uploads/8b3adee052b7782f54c8035755a9ab1c/gnome-sofware-jami-deb.png)

Our guess is that gnome software does not inspect the packages files to search the metadata inside (appdata or debian metadata).

We propose you to show `unknown` instead of `privative` as KDE Discover:

![jami-discover](/uploads/fadb3d11a532cc4b1a600f5ba930c86f/jami-discover.png)

Tested in Debian 9 10, Ubuntu 18.04 19.04, 19.10


This is very important for us as a Free Software project because it impact our reputation, people think we are not fair and we say we are Free Software but we distribute non-free versions from our website.

title: Add a mean to not notify when updates are ready to be installed
description:
OS: Fedora; Component: gnome-software.x86_64 3.34.2-1

Feature request: Add a mean to not notify when updates are ready to be installed. *Cron* does the job at regular intervals.

Actual result:

title: Why are "Spacing" and "The amount of space between children" translatable?
description:
I don't understand why these two strings in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/blob/master/src/gs-hiding-box.c are marked translatable:

```c
	g_object_class_install_property (object_class,
		PROP_SPACING,
		g_param_spec_int ("spacing",
				/* TRANSLATORS: Here are 2 strings the same as in gtk/gtkbox.c
				   in GTK+ project. Please use the same translation. */
				_("Spacing"),
				_("The amount of space between children"),
				0, G_MAXINT, 0,
```

Can someone please explain how and where I can see these strings in the gnome-software UI?

Furthermore, there is no guarantee that these two strings will be shown right next to each other in translation interfaces, so whatever "2 strings" this is about, the translator comment is only shown for the first string and hence confused me.

```

title: Extension enable/disable slider switch missing.
description:
1) Ubuntu 19.10
2) 3.30.6-2ubuntu10.19.10.0
3) If I remember correctly, there was a slider switch in the top right corner of the extension settings window.
4) Extensions are not appearing on the top bar. Extensions appeared before and now they do not appear. I tried removing and reinstalling the extensions.

title: Rethink the add-ons section of the installed list
description:
For me, the add-ons section of the installed list looks like this:

![image](/uploads/afbf32277a38a3fce18b3b1c92c0e19f/image.png)

I think we have to question the appropriateness, intelligibility and usefulness of this section. Most users will look at it and run away. If they do engage with it, they are liable to cause some serious issues.

The problems:

 - It's really hard for non-technical users to understand what the runtimes are.
   - This isn't helped by the names and descriptions of the runtimes being varying degrees of bad. "Freedesktop Platform: Shared libraries" is a particularly fine example.
 - We show the default theme? This also has a terrible description: "Adwaita widget theme matching the GNOME adwaita theme". Thanks.
 - The user can remove any of the runtimes.
   - There's a confirmation dialog when you do this. This has a very standard description ("if you remove this, you'll have to install it again to use it"), which fails to mention what a runtime is or what will actually happen if you remove it.
 - The runtimes, themes and input methods all have the same icon, which doesn't help someone to understand what they are.
 - 40% of the list is the default set of input methods, which you can't remove.

My initial reaction to the list is: why are we even showing this stuff?

title: Reduce frequency of update checks when on a metered network connection
description:
In the responses to the [GNOME metered data survey](https://tecnocode.co.uk/2019/03/21/metered-data-hackfest/), 1.5% of respondents specifically pointed out that updating dnf metadata takes a lot of bandwidth (the metadata is 70MB compressed), which makes quite an impact on a metered connection.

Currently, we have the `refresh-when-metered` GSetting which allows metadata updates to be disabled completely when metered. I was wondering if we could have a middle ground, where `refresh-when-metered` is enabled, but the refresh frequency is lowered compared to when on an unmetered connection. For example, checking for updates once a day rather than hourly. This is just a suggestion to start discussion; I’m sure other solutions are possible.

title: User should be able to set a "Source" preference.
description:
It'd be great to set a preference for a Software source (Distro/Flathub/Third Party repo, etc.) when an app is available from multiple repos.

![Screenshot_from_2019-12-04_22-34-00](/uploads/bfc71d623cb23033a5bda14b9011354c/Screenshot_from_2019-12-04_22-34-00.png)

title: Show download size in Updates
description:
Update size isn't shown on GNOME 3.34 for system updates. Fedora 31.

![Screenshot_from_2019-11-21_10-04-02](/uploads/828a46675131dad98ddf1198a6cf6b6c/Screenshot_from_2019-11-21_10-04-02.png)

title: Show upvotes/downvotes next to reviews on app details page
description:
Currently the ordering for reviews in the app details page is quite opaque (I had to dig through odrs-web to find [`_get_review_score()`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/Infrastructure/odrs-web/blob/a4b674ea063990844263b9fec53dc6c4f1d15d17/app_data/odrs/views_api.py#L37) and found https://gitlab.gnome.org/Infrastructure/odrs-web/issues/3 in the process). Perhaps it would make sense to show the number of upvotes/downvotes next to each review, to allow people to judge how relevant each review is?

Many websites do this, or something like it. Is it something we should consider?

title: Disallow submitting a review for an app you haven’t installed
description:
It seems a bit odd that anyone can use gnome-software to write a review for an app they haven’t installed — the ‘Write a Review’ button is available on all apps’ details pages, even for uninstalled apps.

Should this be allowed? Surely someone should have installed an app in order to fairly review it. On the other hand, they might have just had a bad experience with the app, uninstalled it, and are now ready to write a raw and incisive review of the app’s downsides.

title: Provide feedback in the UI after submitting a review
description:
Currently when submitting a review for an app, the review dialogue disappears and the user is shown the details page for the app again. No errors are shown, but no success message is shown either, and neither is the user’s new review. To me, it felt like my review had been tossed into the bin.

On clicking the ‘Show More’ button in the reviews list on the app’s details page, my review is shown (so it was submitted successfully).

Two ideas:
 * Show a notification saying “Thanks for the review, it’s available for anyone to view already, but will be moderated soon.” (or appropriate words to that effect) at the top of the window. This is easy to do, but a bit clunky.
 * Automatically show the user’s review in the list of reviews, scroll to it, and highlight it. This shows the user the review in its final form, and is perhaps a bit less clunky.

I’m not a designer, so please take my ideas with a big pinch of salt.

title: Flathub Download Size is confusing
description:
The information provided for FlatPak packages is confusing and should be improved.
re: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gnome-software/+bug/1854376

For example, the Flatpak Developer Demo currently shows the following information

Download Size = 918.1 MB
Installed Size = 257.5 KB

This is inconsistent and confusing. For my case, it led me to thinking there was something wrong with flatpak packages. Why are they so huge! Then I had to do some research.

It's my understanding this is due to possibly having to download and install a 'runtime' along with the application. Please correct me if my understanding is incorrect. In this case, as I don't have many flatpak runtimes, the huge download size is probably to download the runtimes. If I download another flatpak using the same runtime, the download size would be much smaller as it would not need to redownload the runtime But the install size is also not really 257.5 KB, as it is also going to install a huge runtime. The reason why we're listing installed size is to give an idea of how much disk space is going to be used anyways.

Proposed resolutions
1. Separate out application and runtimes in the display
    - Download Size = 200 KB, 900 MB runtime
    - Installed Size = 257.5 KB, 900 MB runtime
2. Have both items include the runtime
    - Download Size = 918.1 MB
    - Installed Size = 918.2 MB
3. Have both a total and a breakdown
    - Download Size = 918.1 MB ( 200KB application, 900 MB runtime)
    - Installed Size = 918.2 MB ( 257.5 KB application, 900 MB runtime)
4. Separate out the runtimes as a dependency or something like that
    - Download Size = 200 KB
    - Installed Size = 257.2 KB
    This option is confusing as it would not give a good indicator of how long the download would be. But maybe there is a better way overall to handle dependencies like this in software center, so I just threw this in as an option

title: Consider removing web apps
description:
We've had long-running issues with the web apps, as evidenced by the poor reviews they get. The main issue, I think, is that people don't know what they are when the install them, which leads to disappointment.

One potential answer would be to more prominently advertise what the web apps are. However, the web apps are quite limited in what they do, and it might be better to remove them. It would help to simplify the Software code base. 

Note that I do think that the next generation of web apps - Progressive Web Apps in particular - could be really great for us (see #390).

title: Remove special treatment of fonts
description:
Currently, Software allows someone to browse for and install fonts. I've come to the conclusion that this is a bad idea, for the following reasons:

 - Font search and browsing is quite a specialised thing, and I don't think that Software is invested enough to do a good job of it.
 - You get an extremely limited choice of fonts, if they are provided by a distro.
 - It assumes that fonts are package-based, which doesn't make sense on immutable operating systems.
 - It's yet another type of software that Software has to care about, and adds a bunch of complexity which we'd do well to avoid.

I think we should consider removing the fonts section.

If we care about the fonts experience, we have a Fonts app that we can improve.

title: Crash when opening updates panel with master on Fedora 31
description:
# What Happened

1) Install Fedora 31 in a VM
2) Cloned and built gnome-software from master
3) Opened gnome-software
4) Noted that updates had a number showing updates are available
5) Clicked on updates panel
6) App crashed

# What I expected to happen

At step 6 for the update panel to be shown.

# Details

The crash itself appears to happen here https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/blob/master/src/gs-updates-page.c#L413

Backtrace is below and git was pointing to https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/commit/a75b25d70d157e49a1d327fb5ea653a7bfc3328a when it occurred.

title: "App has been installed" notifications sit around indefinitely
description:
![image](/uploads/4d8f6fd43521930ab28f58d8474a1fd4/image.png)

I installed an app yesterday, and subsequently used it. I don't need the notification any more. It would be better if Software automatically removed it, so users don't have to clean up afterwards.

This was supposedly fixed here: https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=775885

title: Updating Fedora Silverblue, a story of woe
description:
Running Fedora 31 Silverblue:

 - The updates list indicates that there are OS updates to be installed.
 - I click "Update & Restart". The button switches to "Cancel", and nothing happens.
 - I wait. Still nothing happens.
 - Eventually, after some time, I click "Cancel".
 - After a bit more time, a plain "Restart" system dialog pops up (no mention of updates). I assume that it's a delayed request to restart with the new update, so I restart.
 - After restarting I go back to the updates view. No OS updates are listed, so I assume that the update has been installed.
 - After a little while, a notification is shown: "An update has been installed. A restart is required for it to take effect." I click the body of the notification and it disappears.
 - I'm left with no visible way to restart into the new version: there's no indication that there's an update pending, and when I go to restart the system there is no indication that restarting will apply a new version.

During the course of this process, I also tried clicking on a "Restart & Update" button for an outstanding firmware update that I had. That silently disappeared after I clicked it, with no restart dialog or response.

In sum: I'd started out with two updates that I'd wanted to install, had seemingly failed to install both of them, and was left with an updates view that was saying "software is up to date" - leaving me with no visible way to proceed.

title: Can't update Silverblue from F30 to F31
description:
I have a VM running Fedora Silverblue 30 and I wanted to update it to F31 using GNOME Software, but I'm unable to do it.

It looks like the new version is downloaded correctly, but after restart I will end up back in F30. According to jlebon in https://github.com/fedora-silverblue/issue-tracker/issues/20 this is a bug in GNOME Software, which doesn't do deployment of new version.

gnome-software version: 3.34.1

title: Not using orientation metadata when adding a picture of a contact
description:
When I open an image to add a picture of a contact, it seems that the orientation metadata is not used. As can be seen from the screenshot, the image appears correctly in Nautilus but not in Contacts.

```
> exiftool P1070812.JPG | grep Orientation
Orientation                     : Rotate 90 CW
```


![capture_gnome-contacts](/uploads/04da620b9ea3a62b1d34becf6a2184f9/capture_gnome-contacts.jpg)

title: Application level Javascript can lock the ui
description:
This happens intermittently so it is hard to catch logs however I want to open a discussion pertaining to this.

I notice the issue most when using electron applications or the Chrome/Chromium browser however I can trigger the effects with any application that resides in a javascript runtime.

I notice that when anything intense is being done in the background in application level Javascript that it can lock the mouse and ui. This can also trigger the bug that if a key is pressed during the locking gnome will register a keyhold until the locking stops.

I attribute this issue to application level javascript (NOT from `gjs` Javascript) and not from high CPU usage as I can load the CPU with only gtk applications open and the shell will never lock up. This issue appears to *only* happen in webbrowsers during a heavy page load and in electron applications when they do a lot of work. I notice this mostly in VScode because it does a lot of background work on the file system for Intellisense.

title: wayland: can't switch keyboard layouts in a VM when the same key combination is used on the host
description:
### Description
It's not possible to switch the keyboard layout of a shortcut-inhibited VM using the same key combination used to switch the keyboard layout on the host when running in a Wayland session.

The same scenario works as expected when running in an Xorg session.

### Expected behavior
Using `Alt`+`Shift` in a `Boxes` VM should switch the keyboard layout *of the VM*.

### Actual behavior
Using `Alt`+`Shift` in a `Boxes` VM switches the keyboard layout *of the host*.

title: Modal dialogs make parent window show an older state
description:
I'm pretty sure this is a duplicate, but I cannot find an existing bug.

![Screencast_from_23-12-19_22_27_30](/uploads/5c863e2f4129cd32e68c7b9860a0777b/Screencast_from_23-12-19_22_27_30.webm)

![VID_20190920_230300](/uploads/30ebfd2fe2b1007974b3afddb11666dc/VID_20190920_230300.mp4)

The first time a window is dimmed by a modal dialog, it works fine. The second time and subsequently it flickers between the actual state and how it looked with the previous dialog.

title: Gnome-shell performance noticeably BETTER when external monitor connected
description:
Fedora 31, gnome-shell 3.34.2, mutter 3.34.2, wayland

I know, this sounds absolutely illogical and contrary to https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/issues/3 but my animation performance on my laptop is actually noticeably BETTER, when I have an external monitor connected. This is mainly visible during the window overview animation.  
The same effect does NOT apply, when using Xorg.

My setup:  
* Dell XPS 9370 with an i7 8550U and an UHD 620
* The external monitor is a Samsung S24D590PLX
* The external monitor is connected via HDMI through a Dell WD15 Dock 
* Without an external monitor connected my built in monitor runs on 1920 x 1080 @ 60Hz 
* With an external monitor connected both monitors run on 1920 x 1080 @ 60Hz 

Furthermore, I do not find anything noticeable in either `dmesg` or `journalctl /usr/bin/gnome-shell`.

title: Context menu opens and closes immediately when a header bar is right-clicked
description:

Watch the screen recording please. I also can reproduce this issue with nautilus and gnome disks
on both Wayland and x11 sessions.

title: DRM_FORMAT_XRGB2101010 dma buffer format is not handled causing mpv failure on Wayland with Iris Mesa's driver
description:
mpv may use DRM_FORMAT_XRGB2101010 dma buffer however mutter doesn't handle it producing the following error:

```
[destroyed object]: error 7: failed to import supplied dmabufs: Unsupported buffer format 808669784
```

Setup:
- gen8+ Intel GPU (Broadwell and later)
- Mesa >= 19.1
- Wayland
- `MESA_LOADER_DRIVER_OVERRIDE=iris` in `/etc/profile` or `.profile` to enable iris driver
- `mpv --hwdec=no`

In [meta-wayland-dma-buf.c#L98-124](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/blob/e89cea8e5a9c944919cc0632b88bd68432778806/src/wayland/meta-wayland-dma-buf.c#L98-124) I don't see `DRM_FORMAT_XRGB2101010` being handled, only `DRM_FORMAT_ARGB2101010`.

On the other hand mpv may use `XRGB2101010` for the surface [mpv/context_drm_egl.c#L766-L774](https://github.com/mpv-player/mpv/blob/b2b15d4e6e1d92290d0d7e772b9a5468ddea8a81/video/out/opengl/context_drm_egl.c#L766-L774). And by launching mpv with `WAYLAND_DEBUG=1` I see dma buffer with format `808669784` is being created.

Original issue in Mesa: https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/mesa/mesa/issues/2220

title: Refresh rate locked to 60hz on multi-monitor setups when fractional scaling is used (Wayland)
description: I have two monitors connected to my desktop running an up to date Fedora 31 (Gnome 3.34.2 in Wayland) with a Radeon RX 570 as the GPU.  The primary is a 27" 2560x1440 at 144hz and the secondary is a 27" 4K at 60hz.  I like to configure the 4K monitor to have a 150% scale so that it appears the same size as my main 144hz monitor.  When any fractional scaling option is used, the 144hz display only seems to update at 60hz although gnome-settings still shows it configured for 144hz.  This affects all applications and the mouse cursor as well.  When 100% or 200% scaling options are selected for the 4K monitor, the refresh rate on the 144hz monitor appears correct.

title: Several headers don't follow coding style
description: Several header files don't follow the coding style described at https://developer.gnome.org/programming-guidelines/stable/c-coding-style.html.en

title: Glitches and performance issues of the window resize animation
description:
When resizing windows, it (occasionally?/often?) happens that Mutter shows the resized window for a split second before properly starting the resize animation. I see this especially with Firefox on Wayland, which always uses subsurface, therefore taking the [slow path for getting the window image](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/blob/e89cea8e5a9c944919cc0632b88bd68432778806/src/compositor/meta-window-actor.c#L1347).

It is even visible in screencasts: maximizing Firefox two times, once without, once with glitch
![Screencast_from_18.12.2019_21_56_29](/uploads/fb2d4e022ce6084cf7d7d0a090bed4f4/Screencast_from_18.12.2019_21_56_29.webm)

As far as I can see there are two issues at play here:
1.  As getting the image can be slow, the animation is started asynchronously. If the image arrives a frame to late, the resized window is shown in between.
2.  Getting the image is slower then necessary: we take a [full round trip from GPU to RAM and back for the image](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/blob/624cf1dad45bc532beaf0a913743687a65e8c37b/src/shell-util.c#L412-422). I guess this can be pretty bad on 8K screens with dedicated graphic cards. On iGPUs and lower resolutions it should be better as RAM and caches are often shared to a certain extend.

For 1., I wonder if we could somehow delay the actual resize until we're ready to start the animation

For 2., we could probably introduce some clutter content type holding a 'snapshot' of another clutter content, from the moment it is initialized, in an offscreen FB or so.

title: Rethink "rotation" hotkey press behavior
description:
Currently when the rotation hotkey (XF86Rotate) gets pressed we step through the 4 possible rotations for the internal panel.

As discussed in !959, there are 2 issues with this:

1. This is perhaps somewhat weird to do when there also is an accelerometer active for the internal panel
2. It would be nice if the rotation hotkey always works when there is a single active monitor, even if that is an external monitor. The main reason for allowing this is to have a user-story for users with a desktop with a monitor on a stand which can swivel between landscape and portrait modes. On X11 users use one of various X11 utils which can execute a script on a hotkey press (using passive-keygrabs) and then in that script execute xrandr to do the rotation so that they can have hotkeys to adjust the image to which way they have swiveled their monitor. Under Wayland this does not work.

The proposal to fix this is as follows:

1. When XF86Rotate is pressed and there is an active internal panel *and* an accelerometer *and* the orientation is not locked then show the hotkey not available OSD (the one showed when e.g. pressing play/pause and there is no media-player listening)

2. When there is no active internal panel, and only 1 active (other) monitor then step through the 4 possible rotations for that monitor.

As mentioned in !959 it would be good to have a standard pre-defined Super+<key> binding as alternative for XF86Rotate since XF86Rotate is not available on 99.9% of the keyboards, Super+r was my suggestion in !959, but as @hadess mentions there that is "Run" under Windows, so that is not a good idea.

@hadess lets continue our discussion here. Do you agree with my proposal? And any suggestions for a pre-defined hotkey?

title: Can't turn off monitor on wayland
description:
I am using Fedora Gnome 3 with wayland.

After idle time activated, display go to blank. After ~13 seconds monitor show me message "no input was detected", then LED-light on monitor panel turned off and then display activated again! But stay black with mouse visible.

I am easy reproduce this behaviour with command:

`busctl --user set-property org.gnome.Mutter.DisplayConfig /org/gnome/Mutter/DisplayConfig org.gnome.Mutter.DisplayConfig PowerSaveMode i 3`

The display goes off only for ~13 seconds, then activated.

This is very annoying and forces me to turn off the monitor with hardware button.

title: drap and drop not working in 3.4.2 with Wayland
description:
It seems that drag and drop is broken under Wayland. If I switch to xorg, drag and drop works fine. Couple of notes:
- Drag and drop in Nautilus works fine. 
- Dragging from Nautilus into VSCode does not work. 
- Dragging from Firefox to Nautilus works the firs time. After that, drag and drop stops working in Firefox completely, including simple things like links  to the bookmark library. 

I also cannot repro this issue on Fedora with Gnome 3.4.1, this is an issue with Gnome 3.4.2 on Arch.

title: implement layer_shell protocol
description:
The [`wlr_layer_shell_unstable_v1`](https://github.com/swaywm/wlr-protocols/blob/master/unstable/wlr-layer-shell-unstable-v1.xml) protocol provides interfaces to stack shell surfaces and lock them to screen edges. The purpose of these protocols is specifically to implement desktop shells.

An implementation of these interfaces in mutter would allow using mutter as a compositor for a variety of desktop shells, including GNOME Shell itself. A shell would then run as a dedicated Wayland client process, like any other Wayland client.

The biggest advantage of this would be robustness to faults in the shell component. The GNOME Shell process could be restarted arbitrarily, leaving remaining Wayland client connections established. This is comparable to how GNOME Shell is used as X11 window manager, where it can be restarted without terminating the X11 client connections.

title: mutter: Wrong pinch-gesture "dy" values are sent to clients
description: Mutter sends the same value to clients for both `dx` and `dy` in Wayland's `zwp_pointer_gesture_pinch_v1` interface.
